title: Tool breaks when finding Clickjacking vuln using a list
body:
The nettacker tool v0.0.1 breaks when giving a big list of domains for searching clickjacking issue. If in a list the domain is not responding the tool breaks and doesn't check for other domains present down the list. What should happen is the tool should continue checking the list and at the end should display the unavailable domains.
![clickjackingIssue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/32503192/76614322-d772df80-6545-11ea-8232-dbce2ed83fe3.png)


_________________
**OS**: `Linux`

**OS Version**: `Ubuntu`

**Python Version**: `3.6.9`
author: aman566

title: [Low] Inconsistent redundant usage of urllib/urllib2
body:
The file `engine.py` under `http_form` contains the following code:
```
            opener = urllib2.build_opener(
                urllib2.HTTPCookieProcessor(cookiejar))
            . . .
            post_data = urllib.urlencode(parsed_html.parsed_results).encode()
```
`urllib.urlencode` has been pushed into the `urllib.parse.encode` package in Python3, so will throw out an error when used on an Python3 system. Also other `urllib` functions had been pushed into `urllib.request` package. They need to be correctly handled so that both Python2 and Python3 dependencies are met simultaneously.

Fixed by: #224
_________________
**OS**: `Ubuntu`

**OS Version**: `18.04`

**Python Version**: `v3.6`
author: 0xInfection

title: [Low] Deprecated/Removed Libraries
body:
The engine under `http_fuzzer` contains the following imports:
```
from mimetools import Message
from StringIO import StringIO
```
`mimetools` has been deprecated since Python v2.3 and StringIO has been pushed into `io` library for backwards compatibility in v3.x. Using non-existent/deprecated libraries decrease code efficiency as well affects the usability of this framework as a whole. 

> __NOTE__: Python2 's support has been dropped since Jan 2020 and we should too drop Python2 support in near future if not now. :)

Fixed by: #224
_________________
**OS**: `Ubuntu`

**OS Version**: `18.04`

**Python Version**: `v3.6`
author: 0xInfection

title: [Minor] Missing Parenthesis Bug
body:
During the installation of this project an error could be observed:
```
  File "build/bdist.linux-x86_64/egg/lib/payload/scanner/header_blind_sqli/engine.py", line 42
    print e
          ^
SyntaxError: Missing parentheses in call to 'print'. Did you mean print(e)?
```
The engine under `header_blind_sqli` module handles an exception and prints out the exception. However due to the engine code being in a Python2 flavor causes an exception in a Python3 installation, which causes the code to be not byte-complied properly while installation.
 
Fixed by: #224
_________________
**OS**: `Ubuntu`

**OS Version**: `18.04`

**Python Version**: `v3.6`
author: 0xInfection

title: Adding frame-ancestors directive for improving Clickjacking Module
body:
The current Clickjacking module lacks checking Content-Security-Policy header in which frame-ancestors directive needs to be checked if website is vulnerable to clickjacking or not. There are two ways to check whether website is vulnerable to clickjacking or not: x-frame-options header and frame-ancestors directive in CSP header. Adding CSP header check to the Clickjacking module will increase chances of checking the issue
_________________
**OS**: `Linux`

**OS Version**: `Ubuntu`

**Python Version**: `3.x`

title: Using socks proxy template as python decorator
body:
We can use the socks proxy template as a python decorator, instead of repeating the following code every time we can just use a decorator, for e.g. `@socks_proxy` over every function that needs it.

codes...

            if socks_proxy is not None:
                socks_version = socks.SOCKS5 if socks_proxy.startswith('socks5://') else socks.SOCKS4
                socks_proxy = socks_proxy.rsplit('://')[1]
                if '@' in socks_proxy:
                    socks_username = socks_proxy.rsplit(':')[0]
                    socks_password = socks_proxy.rsplit(':')[1].rsplit('@')[0]
                    socks.set_default_proxy(socks_version, str(socks_proxy.rsplit('@')[1].rsplit(':')[0]),
                                            int(socks_proxy.rsplit(':')[-1]), username=socks_username,
                                            password=socks_password)
                    socket.socket = socks.socksocket
                    socket.getaddrinfo = getaddrinfo
                else:
                    socks.set_default_proxy(socks_version, str(socks_proxy.rsplit(':')[0]),
                                            int(socks_proxy.rsplit(':')[1]))
                    socket.socket = socks.socksocket
                    socket.getaddrinfo = getaddrinfo
codes ...

This would reduce the code duplication and the effort to use the above code. Moreover it would help in code-re-usability.
_________________
**OS**: `Kali Linux`

**OS Version**: `2`

**Python Version**: `3.6`

title: core>targets.py  bug
body:
the method "target_type" in core>targets.py  can‘t distinguish some targets like this "Publish_server.oa.xxx.com"。

 I think the right code should be：

`def target_type(target):
    ...
    
    elif re.match('^([a-zA-Z0-9]+(-|_[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*\.?)+[a-z]{2,}$', target):
        return 'DOMAIN'
    elif (target.lower().startswith('http://') or target.lower().startswith('https://')):
        t = target.rsplit("://")[1].rsplit("/")[0].rsplit(":")[0]
        if isIP(t) or isIP6(t) or re.match('^([a-zA-Z0-9]+(-|_[a-zA-Z0-9]+)*\.?)+[a-z]{2,}$', t):
            return 'HTTP'
    elif len(target.rsplit('.')) is 4 and '-' not in target and '/' in target:
        IP, CIDR = target.rsplit('/')
        if isIP(IP) and (int(CIDR) >= 0 and int(CIDR) <= 32):
            return 'CIDR_IPv4'
    return 'UNKNOWN'`
_________________
**OS**: `windows`

**OS Version**: `10`

**Python Version**: `python 2.7.15

title: Fixes for the "Usage" section of docs wiki
body:
I did a basic line edit of the "Usage" section, but next it needs reorganization and more information. 

Would anyone want to spend time on a call or two to help me understand some of the commands? Some of them aren't obvious to me from the command line help, so they might benefit from better explanation.

(I'll continue to work on this section, but having a technical expert to answer some of the questions would be great.)

I think this section would work better by expanding and re-organizing, with the following outline: 

USAGE 

1.) The setup commands  (with a description and example for each)
-language
-verbosity 
- version
- update 
- log in file
- graph 
- help
- wizard 
- profile

2.) Basic command usage
- The base syntax of CLI commands (nettacker -i <targets> -m <methods>)
-Everything you need to know about the targets-related commands (including lists)
-Everything you need to know about the methods-related commands (such as excluding)

3.) More advanced commands 
- users
- users_list
- passwords
- passwords_list
- ports
- timout
- time_sleep
- range
- subdomains
- thread number
- thread_number_host
- socks_proxy
- retries
- ping_before_scan
- methods_args
- methods_args_list

title: if statements
body:
Hello. I want to share a way to make if statements a bit nicer, but I'm not sure whether it's worth a commit ( don't know if you like this way ) or not.

You have a code like this : 
```
if check_subdomains: 
    if check_ranges: 
        if enumerate_flag:

```

You could use:
```
if check_subdomains and check_ranges.....
```
but long lines are against POP, therefore this should work :

```
conditions = [check_ranges, 
enumerate_flag, 
check_subdomains]

if all(conditions):
   print("yay")
```

_Would like to hear your opinion. Cheers_.

title: Documentation: Installation
body:
Two bigger changes that I think would make the installation chapter better:

1.) Fix use of the term "requirements." It appears that it is being used in different ways, which will confuse your end users:

* The summary at the beginning says there are multiple ways to install, including on this list "requirements," which is not exactly a mode of installation.
*The list of pre-requisite software appeared under the heading "requirements." I changed this to "prerequisites," but this calls attention to the issue more than fixing it. 
*There is a script called requirements that installs the actual components of OWASP nettacker. 

Here's what I'd like to do: 
* Move prerequisites higher up in the chapter, because they should be checked before installation begins. Maybe a new section up above installation methods would do it. 
* Remove "requirements" from that list of installation methods 

Let me know if I've misinterpreted anything here. 

2.) Add a support matrix at the top of the installation page, with more detailed information about supported versions of operating systems (e.g. what OSs are actually tested) and any info about problems with individual versions of Python. I would need some feedback for that. 

(I see that there's a line or two in the introduction, but more would be better.)
author: cwcromwell

Best Regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 24, 21, 45, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 400149778, 'issue_id': 335197749, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': "Hey @cwcromwell, I was just going through the changes you made to the installation wiki and it looks clean and more human readable. The current structuring makes it look like a fallback option in case every other step doesn't work. I think we should reorder or reword it better. What do you think?", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 6, 26, 1, 43, 29, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 401618375, 'issue_id': 335197749, 'author': 'cwcromwell', 'body': "I'll take a look.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 7, 1, 16, 46, 51, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 401634594, 'issue_id': 335197749, 'author': 'cwcromwell', 'body': 'I think I've covered all the changes discussed above.

title: Documentation: README
body:
There are some confusing sentences in the README for OWASP-Nettacker.

In the paragraph that starts on line 23 of the README file ("OWASP Nettacker project is created to automate. . .") The last three sentences are difficult to decipher. Here's what they say: 

"This software will utilize TCP SYN, ACK, ICMP and many other protocols in order to detect and bypass firewall/IDS/IPS devices. By leveraging a unique method in OWASP Nettacker for discovering protected services and devices such as SCADA. It would make a competitive edge compared to other scanner making it one of the best."

1.) In that first sentence I can't tell whether the capability exists now or will exist later. 
2.) The next two sentences are incomplete. I can't quite revise these because I'm not sure whether this unique method is the main thing that Nettacker does, or just one of the things. And I might reword this in a way that makes it incorrect.
author: cwcromwell

title: Error in log.py while updating modules to new info messages structure
body:
Got this error while adding new info to modules
```python
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/multiprocessing/process.py", line 267, in _bootstrap
    self.run()
  File "/usr/lib/python2.7/multiprocessing/process.py", line 114, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/root/OWASP-Nettacker/core/attack.py", line 95, in start_attack
    verbose_level, socks_proxy, retries, methods_args, scan_id, scan_cmd)
  File "/root/OWASP-Nettacker/lib/vuln/xdebug_rce/engine.py", line 160, in start
    'CATEGORY': "scan", 'SCAN_ID': scan_id, 'SCAN_CMD': scan_cmd}, log_in_file, language)
  File "/root/OWASP-Nettacker/core/alert.py", line 95, in info
    __log_into_file(thread_tmp_filename, "w", "0", language)
  File "/root/OWASP-Nettacker/core/log.py", line 219, in __log_into_file
    submit_logs_to_db(language, data)
  File "/root/OWASP-Nettacker/database/db.py", line 163, in submit_logs_to_db
    host=log["HOST"], date=log["TIME"], port=log["PORT"], type=log["TYPE"], category=log["CATEGORY"],
TypeError: 'int' object has no attribute '__getitem__'
```
author: pradeepjairamani
comment_thread:
Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-06-23 12:17:48 UTC): Hi,

thanks for reporting, here is a little more details, this problem is coming from `__log_into_file()` when the condition lead the code to `submit_logs_to_db(language, data)` and the data is not `JSON` structure (for instance: `__log_into_file(thread_tmp_filename, 'w', '1', language)` and thread_tmp_filename is not True in this condition `if _builder(_paths(), default_paths())["tmp_path"] in filename:`).


```python
# core/log.py
def __log_into_file(filename, mode, data, language, final=False):
    """
    write a content into a file (support unicode) and submit logs in database. if final=False its writing log in
    the database.

    Args:
        filename: the filename
        mode: writing mode (a, ab, w, wb, etc.)
        data: content
        language: language
        final: True if it's final report otherwise False (default False)

    Returns:
        True if success otherwise None
    """
    if version() is 2:

        if _builder(_paths(), default_paths())["tmp_path"] in filename:
            if not final:
                flock = lockfile.FileLock(filename)
                flock.acquire()
            with open(filename, mode) as save:
                save.write(data + '\n')
            if not final:
                flock.release()
        else:
            if final:
                with open(filename, mode) as save:
                    save.write(data + '\n')
            else:
                submit_logs_to_db(language, data)

    else:

        if _builder(_paths(), default_paths())["tmp_path"] in filename:
            if not final:
                flock = lockfile.FileLock(filename)
                flock.acquire()
            with open(filename, mode, encoding='utf-8') as save:
                save.write(data + '\n')
            if not final:
                flock.release()
        else:
            if final:
                with open(filename, mode, encoding='utf-8') as save:
                    save.write(data + '\n')
            else:
                submit_logs_to_db(language, data)
    return True
```

shaddygarg (Assginee) on (2018-06-23 16:03:20 UTC): @Ali-Razmjoo, should I write a try catch in the database code to give erroneous message if this is done? This will make sure that the developer knows that he is doing something wrong!

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-06-23 16:42:42 UTC): I think we need a better solution, maybe we can check if the data type is JSON/event or not?

title: long startup time
body:
Hello,

While I was testing the framework, I've noticed, it takes a while to run and load module for a simple port scan, but when it's in API mode, it starts immediately, it's simply because in API mode modules are currently loaded on RAM (maybe?) but in CLI it's not, BTW it should not take long like that, if we keep adding modules it will be a waste of time to keep waiting for CLI scans. We need to find out where we've done wrong and fix it up.

Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

title: Include Ubuntu binary dependencies in README
body:
Please Describe the issue or question and share your OS and Python version.
_________________
**OS**: `Ubuntu`

**OS Version**: `16.04 - 18.04`

**Python Version**: `2 or 3`

The readme needs installation instructions for Ubuntu that include binary dependencies from `apt`.

```
sudo apt-get install libcurl4-openssl-dev libssl-dev
```

The Python development package was also needed at some point:

- Python 2: `python-dev`
- Python 3: `python3-dev`

title: Long targets calculating
body:
Hello,

I just notice that it takes much time to start the scanning, this delay comes from IP range calculating and finding out the total targets number.

```python
python nettacker.py -i 10.0.0.0-10.255.255.255 -m port_scan
python nettacker.py -i 10.0.0.0/8 -m port_scan
```

I think we can use a better algorithm like:

```python
In [1]: import ipaddress
   ...: ip1 = int(ipaddress.IPv4Address(unicode('10.0.0.0')))
   ...: ip2 = int(ipaddress.IPv4Address(unicode('10.255.255.255')))
   ...: print ip2 - ip1
   ...:
16777215
```

Best Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

title: Improve Service Scanner Signatures
body:
Hello,

Thanks to @pradeepjairamani for contribution #148, now we have a service scanner, which we need to improve by adding more signatures in it! there are a few documents for its usage in [here](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/tree/master/lib/payload/scanner/service) and also its implemented in `port_scan` module!

To add signatures, you may take a look at the conditions in [engine.py](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/blob/master/lib/payload/scanner/service/engine.py#L23).

there are two types of conditions, first one is `and` conditions. it contains an array of conditions, conditions type could be a string or an array. if the condition type is the string, then it must be in the response data, if it's array, one of the strings in the array must be in the response data. for instance:
```python
[True and True [True or False or True] and True]
```
a real example condition:
```python
ports_services_and_condition = {
    "http": [["HTTP/0.9", "HTTP/1.0", "HTTP/1.1", "HTTP/2.0"]],
    "ftp": ["FTP", ["214", "220", "530", "230", "502", "500"]],
    "ssh": ["SSH"],
    "telnet": ["Telnet"],
    "smtp": ["SMTP", ["220", "554", "250"]],
    "imap": ["IMAP"],
    "mariadb": ["MariaDB"],
    "mysql": ["MySQL"],
}
```

the second type of condition is `or`, it contains an array of conditions, conditions type could be a string or an array. if the condition is a string, one of the strings must be in response data or if it's an array, all of the strings in the array must be in the response data. for instance:

```python
[True or True or [True and False and True] or True]
```
a real example condition:

```python
ports_services_or_condition = {
    "http": ["400 Bad Request", "401 Unauthorized", "302 Found", "Server: cloudflare", "404 Not Found", "HTML", "Content-Length:", "Content-Type:"],
    "ftp": [["Pure-FTPd", "----------\r\n"], "\r\n220-You are user number", ["orks FTP server", "VxWorks VxWorks"],
            "530 USER and PASS required", "Server ready.\r\n5", "Invalid command: try being more creative", "220 Hotspot FTP server (MikroTik 6.27) ready", "220 SHARP MX-M264N Ver 01.05.00.0n.16.U FTP server.",
            "220 Microsoft FTP Service", "220 FTP Server ready.", "220 Microsoft FTP Service", "220 Welcome to virtual FTP service.", "220 DreamHost FTP Server", "220 FRITZ!BoxFonWLAN7360SL(UI) FTP server ready."],
    "ssh": ["-OpenSSH_", "\r\nProtocol mism", "_sshlib GlobalSCAPE\r\n", "\x00\x1aversion info line too long"],
    "telnet": ["Welcome to Microsoft Telnet Service", "no decompiling or reverse-engineering shall be allowed",
               "is not a secure protocol", "recommended to use Stelnet", "Login authentication"],
    "smtp": ["Server ready", "SMTP synchronization error", "220-Greetings", "ESMTP Arnet Email Security", "SMTP 2.0",
             "Fidelix Fx2020"],
    "imap": ["BAD Error in IMAP command received by server", "IMAP4rev1 SASL-IR", "OK [CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1",
             "LITERAL+ SASL-IR LOGIN-REFERRALS ID ENABLE IDLE NAMESPACE AUTH=PLAIN AUTH=LOGIN]",
             "LITERAL+ SASL-IR LOGIN-REFERRALS ID ENABLE IDLE AUTH=PLAIN AUTH=LOGIN AUTH=DIGEST-MD5 AUTH=CRAM-MD5]"],
    "mariadb": ["is not allowed to connect to this MariaDB server", "5.5.52-MariaDB", "5.5.5-10.0.34-MariaDB"],
    "mysql": ["is not allowed to connect to this MySQL server"]
}
```

You can collect the data and find services from [shodan.io](https://shodan.io), or use `discovery()` on your network and find out which port/service is `UNKNOWN`. then grab some signatures and add it to the framework.

```python
In [1]: from lib.payload.scanner.service.engine import discovery

In [2]: discovery("127.0.0.1")
Out[2]:
{80: 'http',
 443: 'http/ssl',
 445: 'UNKNOWN',
 902: 'UNKNOWN',
 912: 'UNKNOWN',
 2179: 'UNKNOWN',
 3306: 'mariadb',
 6000: 'UNKNOWN'}
```

Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

title: Implement new HTTP Fuzzer into HTTP-Based modules
body:
Hello,

Now we have a simple HTTP Fuzzer/Repeater [available](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/pull/147/) in the framework that could help us to remove duplicate codes, please consider the `pma_scan` module as an example of implementing of this fuzzer. The documentation is also available in code, readme file. (and will be avalaibe in wiki soon)

Regards.

title: Clean Code
body:
Hey,

I found a few cool references to explain the clean-code in python. We already implementing base on them but we miss a few sections! it will be awesome to review the code and clean up what we missed!

* fix conditions 
* fix names
* remove duplicates and repeated code
* code-based documentions
* PEP8
* etc.


Regards.

## Refrences
* https://github.com/zedr/clean-code-python
* https://github.com/rmariano/Clean-code-in-Python/blob/master/build/Clean%20code%20in%20Python.pdf
author: Ali-Razmjoo

title: Add SSL Support for API/WebUI
body:
Hey,

I think we can add SSL (HTTPS) for our API service as an optional feature, They can add their own keys/certs and also we can generate one for them, Flask is already supporting SSL.

* [Flask](http://flask.pocoo.org/snippets/111/)
* [Generate SSL Cert with Python](https://gist.github.com/ril3y/1165038)

Regards.

title: Use introjs to create a tutorial for the web API view
body: [IntroJS](https://introjs.com/) is a library used to create awesome tutorial generally when the user opens the site for the first time. In our case, we can have the tutorial tab specifically made in the web view or the tutorial could be deployed on a demo website. Please let me know if you have any other ideas.

title: bytes should convert to str
body:
Hey,

I was testing the framework on a VM, and found this error.

```python
Exception in thread Thread-1:
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/threading.py", line 911, in _bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/threading.py", line 859, in run
    self._target(*self._args, **self._kwargs)
  File "/root/owasp-nettacker/lib/scan/wappalyzer/engine.py", line 162, in analyze
    obj = json.loads(pkg_resources.resource_string(__name__, "apps.json"))
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.4/json/__init__.py", line 312, in loads
    s.__class__.__name__))
TypeError: the JSON object must be str, not 'bytes'
```
As it looks, we forget to convert bytes to str to prevent error in Python 3.

Regards.
_________________
**OS**: `CentOS`

**OS Version**: `6.5`

**Python Version**: `3.4.5`
author: Ali-Razmjoo

title: Implementing Service scanning in OWASP-Nettacker
body:
OWASP-Nettacker currently lacks the power of scanning a network for running services
before doing vulnerability assessment and sending payloads; hence every attack can end up
useless if the service is running at a different port.
Let’s take an example, when doing network scanning if a Secure Socket Layer is running on a
port or if the port is using an SSL tunnel in order to protect its users from MITM attack then we
first scan that service for SSL vulnerabilities like CCS injection, Heartbleed, Logjam, Poodle,
and many others in order to keep the tunnel secure and the user’s data protected, this will boost the discovery rate of vulnerabilities.

For services like SSH, SMTP, FTP and other common services we will be using normal banner
grabbing techniques where Python sockets will be used. A typical FTP banner gives us
information about the product and version being used on FTP service that is Bftpd 1.6.6 which
could enumerate multiple vulnerabilities without sending any payloads to the server.

`[+] 192.168.2.1:220 bftpd 1.6.6 at 192.168.2.1 ready.`

For services like HTTP/HTTPS, we will be using Python-Requests module which will be helpful
for detecting the server running by header information, a typical header looks like this which
gives us information about the running services & version on the port which is Nginx/1.10.3 and
the OS details which is Linux Ubuntu.

`({'date': 'Thu, 08 Mar 2018 14:23:48 GMT', 'connection': 'keep-alive', 'content-encoding': 'gzip',
'x-powered-by': 'Express', 'content-type': 'text/html; charset=utf-8', 'vary': 'Accept-Encoding',
'cache-control': 'public, max-age=0', 'etag': 'W/"3b51-DSUPhtrEeYNRRot/gk1jUt+PAnc"',
'server': 'nginx/1.10.3 (Ubuntu)', 'transfer-encoding': 'chunked'})`

Many DNS servers are pre-configured with version information in DNS TXT records for the version bind label in the CHAOS class.

`dig @dns.name.server version.bind chaos txt`

Typical answers might include

`;; ANSWER SECTION:
version.bind. 0 CH TXT "9.8.1-P1"`
OR
`;; ANSWER SECTION:
version.bind. 1476526080 IN TXT "Microsoft DNS 6.1.7600 (1DB04228)"`
OR
`;; ANSWER SECTION:
version.bind. 0 CH TXT "dnsmasq-2.47"`

Same can be implemented using **nslookup** ​for Windows ​system.

All the previous modules will be shifted to Service based detection instead of port-based detection after this implementation for better results.
author: pradeepjairamani
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 384043085, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': '@pradeepjairamani 
Currently I am working on this. And my whole idea to get service information. If port is open then
it may give  easily banner grabbing. But when any port  is filtered then we bypass it by fragmentation 
of IP-address.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 18, 58, 48, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384044740, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': "@VictorSuraj I don't understand the part fragmentation of Ip-address.
I will be using normal socket connect for open port detection, please explain your idea.

Best Regards", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 4, 18, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384047514, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': 'fragmentation means as a spoofed ip-address for the server where we want to send our packets.
socket well work in banner grabbing but sometimes it is failed. because of, if server self response
about there service then we grab banner through socket. But If server is not configured to give any response  then socket failed there.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 14, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384048306, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey @VictorSuraj,

Is this need to create a raw socket? can you share a few references for your idea, it seems cool!

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 16, 59, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384048401, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': 'fragmentation means not a spoofed ip-address but firewall of server cant detect our IP-address.
because  our IP-address information goes in server as in fragments(8-bit or 16-bit at a time of total 32-bit.)', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 17, 20, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384049512, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'abiusx', 'body': '@VictorSuraj Can you please point to a scenario in which a socket attempt is not useful by fragmentation is? Please describe a service that we can setup and test, so that we can work on the solution.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 21, 20, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384049804, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': 'my code is not currently ready. But I have a simple example.
Some times while scanning about in services by nmap a output comes out as " server block our ping probes". So here we use a switch -Pn .   I see some working of switch -Pn used by nmap.
And I found that it sends our IP-address in fragments.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 22, 22, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384050559, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': 'switch "-Pn" used in nmap for bypass firewall so my idea to grab enough  information about any port's services. I am using scapy for this task. Scapy covered many points at a time so that our code work much faster and determine more information.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 24, 56, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384051143, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'abiusx', 'body': 'Yes, but ping uses ICMP protocol which is a lower level protocol compared to TCP, so it can not be done with sockets. However, all TCP services work with a socket.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 27, 2, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384051312, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'I am not sure about nmap structure, but in the help menu says ` -Pn: Treat all hosts as online -- skip host discovery`, I though nmap use SYN/ACK to bypass some firewalls and grab information (such as OS and OS Version)', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 27, 35, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384051648, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': "@VictorSuraj  switch -Pn is not a firewall evasion technique, It just doesn't checks if the server is offline or online and scans all the open ports.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 28, 47, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384053135, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'VictorSuraj', 'body': '@abiusx 
While connecting to a filtered port. socket can not work here. A timeout definitely comes out.
So for this purpose we need fragmentation and I think nettacker used scapy. And we can do a lot
with this. please If you give me some more about socket in fragmentation then send me. I read it
and response  soon.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 33, 58, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384054419, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': "@VictorSuraj  I haven't worked much with scapy, but can you demonstrate a code where we can see different closed ports and filtered ports?

Best Regards", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 38, 34, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384054431, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'correct, we used scapy, but I will glad if we can find or create a replacement, we already have some license issues, if we can remove requirements it would us so much, so any contribution in this area are so welcomed.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 19, 38, 39, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 384055925, 'issue_id': 317056849, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': '@pradeepjairamani thanks for mentioning this, I also looking forward to see a sample code to improve our libraries. 

in any case if you need a test server to scan, we have a closed port `3389` on our server `nettacker.z3r0d4y.com`  that you have permission to do all your tests. also, you are permitted to do test for the filtered ports on `zdresearch.com`.

comment_thread:
VictorSuraj on (2018-04-24 18:58:48 UTC): @pradeepjairamani 
Currently I am working on this. And my whole idea to get service information. If port is open then
it may give  easily banner grabbing. But when any port  is filtered then we bypass it by fragmentation 
of IP-address.

pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-24 19:04:18 UTC): @VictorSuraj I don't understand the part fragmentation of Ip-address.
I will be using normal socket connect for open port detection, please explain your idea.

Best Regards

VictorSuraj on (2018-04-24 19:14:04 UTC): fragmentation means as a spoofed ip-address for the server where we want to send our packets.
socket well work in banner grabbing but sometimes it is failed. because of, if server self response
about there service then we grab banner through socket. But If server is not configured to give any response  then socket failed there.

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-24 19:16:59 UTC): Hey @VictorSuraj,

Is this need to create a raw socket? can you share a few references for your idea, it seems cool!

Regards.

VictorSuraj on (2018-04-24 19:17:20 UTC): fragmentation means not a spoofed ip-address but firewall of server cant detect our IP-address.
because  our IP-address information goes in server as in fragments(8-bit or 16-bit at a time of total 32-bit.)

abiusx on (2018-04-24 19:21:20 UTC): @VictorSuraj Can you please point to a scenario in which a socket attempt is not useful by fragmentation is? Please describe a service that we can setup and test, so that we can work on the solution.

VictorSuraj on (2018-04-24 19:22:22 UTC): my code is not currently ready. But I have a simple example.
Some times while scanning about in services by nmap a output comes out as " server block our ping probes". So here we use a switch -Pn .   I see some working of switch -Pn used by nmap.
And I found that it sends our IP-address in fragments.

VictorSuraj on (2018-04-24 19:24:56 UTC): switch "-Pn" used in nmap for bypass firewall so my idea to grab enough  information about any port's services. I am using scapy for this task. Scapy covered many points at a time so that our code work much faster and determine more information.

abiusx on (2018-04-24 19:27:02 UTC): Yes, but ping uses ICMP protocol which is a lower level protocol compared to TCP, so it can not be done with sockets. However, all TCP services work with a socket.

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-24 19:27:35 UTC): I am not sure about nmap structure, but in the help menu says ` -Pn: Treat all hosts as online -- skip host discovery`, I though nmap use SYN/ACK to bypass some firewalls and grab information (such as OS and OS Version)

pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-24 19:28:47 UTC): @VictorSuraj  switch -Pn is not a firewall evasion technique, It just doesn't checks if the server is offline or online and scans all the open ports.

VictorSuraj on (2018-04-24 19:33:58 UTC): @abiusx 
While connecting to a filtered port. socket can not work here. A timeout definitely comes out.
So for this purpose we need fragmentation and I think nettacker used scapy. And we can do a lot
with this. please If you give me some more about socket in fragmentation then send me. I read it
and response  soon.

pradeepjairamani (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-24 19:38:34 UTC): @VictorSuraj  I haven't worked much with scapy, but can you demonstrate a code where we can see different closed ports and filtered ports?

Best Regards

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-24 19:38:39 UTC): correct, we used scapy, but I will glad if we can find or create a replacement, we already have some license issues, if we can remove requirements it would us so much, so any contribution in this area are so welcomed.

in any case if you need a test server to scan, we have a closed port `3389` on our server `nettacker.z3r0d4y.com`  that you have permission to do all your tests. also, you are permitted to do test for the filtered ports on `zdresearch.com`.

title: Implementing Text/JSON Database for non-fuzzer based vulnerabilities
body:
In Non-fuzzer based Network Vulnerability tests, there is no fuzzing and all the tests are done using information of the services running on the port like product and version detection of the service.
Take an example of Proftpd which is one of the most common FTP services across Linux
systems. There are many exploits for the older versions of Proftpd

[ProFTPd CVEDetails](https://www.cvedetails.com/product/16873/Proftpd-Proftpd.html?vendor_id=9520)

Just the product and version detection of those services can be used to find vulnerabilities inside
a network and the vendors update the product instead of sending patches to the users.

To implement this functionality, we will create new modules or create a database of vulnerable
versions of different products that are running on different services.

This will make the testing faster; more modules will be added in a short time and also these tests
won't harm the system as these tests only use banner grabbing technique
author: pradeepjairamani

title: Implementing SSL vulnerability Scanner
body: Implementing SSL based vulnerabilities like SSL logjam, SSL drown, SSL Poodle, SSL crime, TLS fallback, SSL lucky13, Weak DH ciphers and many others by enumerating server ciphers and also by detecting which SSL/TLS versions are being used in the server.
author: pradeepjairamani

title: Code Coverage Service Solution
body:
Hello,

As you may know, I could not setup code coverage on the Travis-CI, it does not support environment variable when PR receive from other contributors, and BTW if it supports it's not safe (token could be printed in PR).

I think about two solutions for this.

* Create a service on could server and run it after every PR on my VPS.
* Add a script to the project and do the code coverage whenever I send a commit and environment variable `CODACY_PROJECT_TOKEN` is exist!

Let me know if you have any idea to fix it up.

Best Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 384126753, 'issue_id': 316977851, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey,

temporarily I've added simple test for code coverage. whenever the EV is present it will do the test (when ever I push the code), BTW we are as you can see in [here](https://app.codacy.com/app/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/dashboard) our code coverage unit test is 32%, so let's improve that! I think we need to [combine](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26214055/combine-python-coverage-files) some tests, any idea?

```bash
 if [[ ${#CODACY_PROJECT_TOKEN} == 32 ]];
    then
      coverage run nettacker.py -i 127.0.0.1 -m all -t 1000 &&
      coverage report -m &&
      coverage xml &&
      python-codacy-coverage -r coverage.xml;
      else
        echo "skip code coverage section";
 fi;
```

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 25, 1, 0, 30, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-25 01:00:30 UTC): Hey,

temporarily I've added simple test for code coverage. whenever the EV is present it will do the test (when ever I push the code), BTW we are as you can see in [here](https://app.codacy.com/app/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/dashboard) our code coverage unit test is 32%, so let's improve that! I think we need to [combine](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/26214055/combine-python-coverage-files) some tests, any idea?

```bash
 if [[ ${#CODACY_PROJECT_TOKEN} == 32 ]];
    then
      coverage run nettacker.py -i 127.0.0.1 -m all -t 1000 &&
      coverage report -m &&
      coverage xml &&
      python-codacy-coverage -r coverage.xml;
      else
        echo "skip code coverage section";
 fi;
```

Regards.

Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

title: Bring ML to OWASP Nettacker
body:
Hello,

As you know, OWASP Nettacker logs every event in the database, after a while, you will have enough data to use them for machine learning to find the risks easier. I am not an expert in AI/ML so I cannot tell, but I have a few ideas. for instance, we have a company with an internal network (include 10,000 IPs), I can tell it's easy to set a cronjob and analysis the network hourly, but it's a little bit hard to monitor the events! that's where I would like to use ML to create diagrams/charts to monitor the events in WebUI. To be sure if it's possible and this theory is not wrong, I will ask Dr. Vahid Behzadan (@behzadanksu) to guide us in this case and will let you know the updates.


I know we can do better with the data, so I am glad to send me your ideas to work on.

Best Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

title: Update Switch
body:
Hello,

As you know, the update switch is a decorate now and does not work, I did not add it because we had not any release! before adding this feature I want to ask the ideas to get to know our users.

As you can see in the [core/update.py](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/blob/master/core/update.py), I `http://nettacker.z3r0d4y.com/version.py` to check the latest version number from GitHub and compare it with users version to tell if the latest or not, but I could do it by directly with requesting to the GitHub.

The reason I did not do that, it's because GitHub won't share us the analytics and information regarding our users, by that method I could see where the users come from (at least) by their IP location, to guess and provide the languages they may use in the framework. also as you know, check for update is a startup event, so I could understand how many times our scanner begin used (not accurate because it could be used in local networks or check for the update could be disabled in [config.py](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/blob/master/core/config.py#L111)).

BTW I was thinking if we could get more legal/public information about our users (like the operation system, python version, etc) to do more tests and provide better service. but keep in mind we cannot touch any sensitive information to prevent any information leakage and more. We can do it on the "User-Agent" while the user is connecting to our server to check for updates.

We can also show the information on a graph to the public on our website (like must used by GEO, python versions, OS type and so on).

The reason for this update is I am feeling we are wasting our time on supporting Windows OS, the data will define our path and focus.

let me know if you have any idea regarding this.

Best Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

title: Security issue (try, except, pass)

Regards.

title: New target_type structure
body:
Hello,

We are using `target_type` (from [core/targets.py](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/blob/master/core/targets.py#L32)) to define the target type (`HTTP`, `SINGLE_IPv4`, `SINGLE_IPv6`, `RANGE_IPv4`, etc...). 

It's best to improve the URL section to detect the URL types such as (`ssh`, `ftp`, `smtp`, etc..) to make it work better!

Regards.

title: New events and alerts(I/O) system
body:
Hello,

As you know, we are using [alerts](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/wiki/Developers#alerts) (`info`, `warn`, `error`) to print on the screen and `__log_into_file` save an event to the [database](https://github.com/zdresearch/OWASP-Nettacker/wiki/Developers#log-in-database-or-file) or write a file. This code repeated in the entire project several times, to improve our code quality, we can convert the alerts to a new class and every time we need to log an event (events always get printed too), do it with the same class we used to alert the users.

* as an example

```python
# currently
info("our message/event")

# update
info("our message/event")  # this would not log as event in database
info("our message/event", event={"USERNAME": "", "SCAN_ID": "1a7d86550d22c59fdef6bc94da440d81",
                                 "DESCRIPTION": "22/TCP_CONNECT", "TIME": "2018-04-23 23:27:34", "PASSWORD": "",
                                 "TYPE": "port_scan", "HOST": "127.0.0.1", "PORT": 22})

```

Best Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 379477957, 'issue_id': 312215878, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey Shaddy,

thanks for creating the issue, I think we may create a new `dict` for synonyms, in that case, we can locate it in the `core/config.py`.

```python
def _profiles():
    """
    a shortcut and users profile to run customize scans (could be modify by user)
    Returns:
        a JSON contains profile names and module names for each
    """
    return {
        "information_gathering": ["port_scan"],
        "vulnerability": ["*_vuln"],
        "scan": ["*_scan"],
        "brute": ["*_brute"]
    }

def _synonym_profile():
    return {
        "info": "information_gathering",
        "vuln": "vulnerability",
    }
```

we should also modify `core/args_load.py` and `api/api_core.py->__rules` to apply synonyms and replace them. in this way, synonyms will not be shown in web or API. let me know if you would like work on this, and if it's little complicated, I can take care of it.

Best Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 7, 15, 34, 43, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 379478818, 'issue_id': 312215878, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': 'Hey Ali,
I would love to work on this issue. Along with this, I think we should also make change in `api/api_core.py->__scan_methods` to prevent it from showing in HTML view. I am however unsure about the change in core/args_load.py. Are we looking to exclude these in the arguments too?
Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 7, 15, 46, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 379483679, 'issue_id': 312215878, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'in that case, you can remove the synonyms from there, but if we have to define synonyms first!', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 7, 16, 55, 37, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 379484142, 'issue_id': 312215878, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': 'The synonyms can be defined in the `core/config.py` file and the `api/api_core.py`can import them to exclude from the profiles shown in the API and the web view. I have implemented the same in #104.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 7, 17, 2, 41, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 382904712, 'issue_id': 312215878, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': 'Closed via #104', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 19, 22, 53, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-07 15:34:43 UTC): Hey Shaddy,

thanks for creating the issue, I think we may create a new `dict` for synonyms, in that case, we can locate it in the `core/config.py`.

```python
def _profiles():
    """
    a shortcut and users profile to run customize scans (could be modify by user)
    Returns:
        a JSON contains profile names and module names for each
    """
    return {
        "information_gathering": ["port_scan"],
        "vulnerability": ["*_vuln"],
        "scan": ["*_scan"],
        "brute": ["*_brute"]
    }

def _synonym_profile():
    return {
        "info": "information_gathering",
        "vuln": "vulnerability",
    }
```

we should also modify `core/args_load.py` and `api/api_core.py->__rules` to apply synonyms and replace them. in this way, synonyms will not be shown in web or API. let me know if you would like work on this, and if it's little complicated, I can take care of it.

Best Regards.

shaddygarg (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-07 15:46:04 UTC): Hey Ali,
I would love to work on this issue. Along with this, I think we should also make change in `api/api_core.py->__scan_methods` to prevent it from showing in HTML view. I am however unsure about the change in core/args_load.py. Are we looking to exclude these in the arguments too?
Regards.

Ali-Razmjoo on (2018-04-07 16:55:37 UTC): in that case, you can remove the synonyms from there, but if we have to define synonyms first!

shaddygarg (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-07 17:02:41 UTC): The synonyms can be defined in the `core/config.py` file and the `api/api_core.py`can import them to exclude from the profiles shown in the API and the web view. I have implemented the same in #104.

shaddygarg (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-19 22:53:10 UTC): Closed via #104

I glad if anyone could help on this.

Regards.

title: join multiple vulnerability scanner
body:
Hello,

I notice we added multiple modules to check the HTTP headers for misconfiguration/vulnerabilities  (e.g. xss protection, content type, etc.. ). It's best to join them into one module and keep the vulnerability information in a JSON and we can name it `header_based_vuln?`.

I glad if someone could work on this.

Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 378037394, 'issue_id': 310219307, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'how about making a directory structure for different vulnerabilities rather than having to combine all those vulnerabilities in one module as in if another developer wants to create a vulnerability for eg. header_based_vuln he will have to understand the entire data present in that module and editing those previously stable modules can cause instability and confusion.

Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 2, 20, 40, 16, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 378207120, 'issue_id': 310219307, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey @pradeepjairamani,

 I am not sure I quite understand you, could you please explain more?

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 3, 10, 43, 18, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 378208405, 'issue_id': 310219307, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'So, you are asking to combine multiple modules into one single module which means a single engine.py for all the http header based vulnerabilities?
Doing that might create confusion for new developers and also can make the already stable modules unstable with each vulnerability being added. 
Better we should make folder structure like we discussed in cms scanner.

http_header_vuln > options_method >engine.py
http_header_vuln > XSS_protection  >engine.py
http_header_vuln > clickjacking >engine.py , etc


Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 3, 10, 48, 57, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 378213198, 'issue_id': 310219307, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': "I get it! Until http_header_vuln > engine.py be exist,  it's not a problem!", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 3, 11, 9, 51, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 378214240, 'issue_id': 310219307, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Meaning?', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 3, 11, 14, 4, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 378214692, 'issue_id': 310219307, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'I meant we can combine modules just like you suggested. every module in a category could be in a subdirectory as a class.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 3, 11, 15, 59, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
pradeepjairamani on (2018-04-02 20:40:16 UTC): how about making a directory structure for different vulnerabilities rather than having to combine all those vulnerabilities in one module as in if another developer wants to create a vulnerability for eg. header_based_vuln he will have to understand the entire data present in that module and editing those previously stable modules can cause instability and confusion.

Best Regards

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-03 10:43:18 UTC): Hey @pradeepjairamani,

 I am not sure I quite understand you, could you please explain more?

Regards.

pradeepjairamani on (2018-04-03 10:48:57 UTC): So, you are asking to combine multiple modules into one single module which means a single engine.py for all the http header based vulnerabilities?
Doing that might create confusion for new developers and also can make the already stable modules unstable with each vulnerability being added. 
Better we should make folder structure like we discussed in cms scanner.

http_header_vuln > options_method >engine.py
http_header_vuln > XSS_protection  >engine.py
http_header_vuln > clickjacking >engine.py , etc


Best Regards

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-03 11:09:51 UTC): I get it! Until http_header_vuln > engine.py be exist,  it's not a problem!

pradeepjairamani on (2018-04-03 11:14:04 UTC): Meaning?

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-03 11:15:59 UTC): I meant we can combine modules just like you suggested. every module in a category could be in a subdirectory as a class.

title: Join the OWASP ZSC to this framework?
body:
Hello,

To clarify, OWASP ZSC [[1](https://github.com/viraintel/OWASP-ZSC)] is open source software written in python which lets you generate customized shellcode and convert scripts to an obfuscated script. This software can be run on Windows/Linux/OSX with python. 

Bringing OWASP ZSC to this project may help us to generate the trustable payloads for exploits (vulnerabilities category), also after testing a vulnerability, it could be useful for Back-Connect or Meterpreter. 

Whats your idea to join these two projects together?  Should OWASP ZSC add az a library or module or the both?

* I prefer to add the OWASP ZSC as a library first so other modules could use it easily.
* OWASP ZSC Modules are not written really standard and we must rewrite them!

Feel free to share your idea.

Best Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 375004674, 'issue_id': 307245002, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': 'Hey, 

This is a great idea. I also think that OWASP ZSC should be added as a library like the icmp library so that other modules can use it to generate payloads. It would be a great addition to the existing framework. I am currently going through the ZSC code to see the way the modules are written. 

Best Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 21, 16, 24, 55, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 375017545, 'issue_id': 307245002, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Hello,

I think first of all adding ZSC to this project is a great idea and we should add ZSC as a library because all the modules will be using that.
Secondly, msfvenom and OWASP-ZSC nearly perform the same tasks so giving user the options of exploitation using both will be a good idea. Default option for exploitation will be fron ZSC because 
of licensing problems.
References: https://github.com/rapid7/metasploit-framework/blob/master/LICENSE', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 21, 16, 59, 1, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 375219504, 'issue_id': 307245002, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey,

title: Adding more data to vuln modules
body:
Proposed additional data to be added in vulnerability modules: 

Name
Description
Risk rating
CVE
Solution
References
author: pradeepjairamani
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 372698349, 'issue_id': 304560025, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hello, 

Thanks for updating with this issue, it's actually a very good idea, let's grab a few references first. as you sent me we can use OWASP risk rating for the "risk rating".

Please provide a few more references and standards. 

Thanks.


* https://www.owasp.org/index.php/OWASP_Risk_Rating_Methodology', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 13, 15, 7, 1, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 372703163, 'issue_id': 304560025, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'Every Vulnerability has a CVE, and by searching that CVE we can find all the details about it.

title: args_loader upgrade
body:
Hello,

according to #60 issue, the `core/args_loader.py` is not working well and does not consider all possible commands. we can add a task to replace `--method-args port_scan_stealth` with `--method-args port_scan_stealth=True`. the default values for any `key` would be `True`.

e.g. `--method-args port_scan_stealth&port_scan_ports=1,2,3&dir_scan_random_agent` would be equal to `--method-args port_scan_stealth=True&port_scan_ports=1,2,3&dir_scan_random_agent=True`

let me know if anyone would like to work on this.

Best Regards.

title: module http_ntlm_brute is not available
body:
Hello,

check the latest test on [TravisCI](https://travis-ci.org/viraintel/OWASP-Nettacker), this module having some errors.
```
[+] start attacking 127.0.0.1, 14 of 29
[X] this module "http_ntlm_brute" is not available
[!] unable to open http://127.0.0.1/
[+] start attacking 127.0.0.1, 16 of 29
[+] start attacking 127.0.0.1, 18 of 29
[+] start attacking 127.0.0.1, 17 of 29
[X] this module "http_form_brute" is not available
[+] start attacking 127.0.0.1, 19 of 29
[+] trying 1 of 16 in process 3 of 29 127.0.0.1:21 (telnet_brute)
```
Regards.
_________________
**OS**: `Linux`

**OS Version**: `using TravisCI`

**Python Version**: `2.x`, `3.x`
author: Ali-Razmjoo
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 372129923, 'issue_id': 304172800, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': 'Hey,
I will have a look into it and send a fix soon. 
Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 11, 16, 49, 40, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 376690463, 'issue_id': 304172800, 'author': 'JeckyOH', 'body': '@Ali-Razmjoo 
The reason of this issue is the ImportError of pycurl module in lib.brute.http_ntlm.py.
The error looks like this: 
`ImportError: pycurl: libcurl link-time ssl backend (openssl) is different from compile-time ssl backend (none/other)`
It is apparent that pycurl is compiled without specifying the backend as openssl.
Here is the solution: [Solution of different backend of PyCurl between link time and compile time](http://pycurl.io/docs/latest/install.html).
Just reinstall pycurl with specifying the backend as openssl:
`pip uninstall pycurl` 
`echo PYCURL_SSL_LIBRARY=openssl` 
`pip install --compile pycurl`
I have tried to use this method on Linux Ubuntu and it can solve this issue. However, in Mac OS 10.13, it failed.
Because this is the error of compiling PyCurl, which is installed through requirements.txt and I`m afraid of disrupting the structure of the project, I cannot provide a PR to solve this problem.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 27, 22, 2, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383962972, 'issue_id': 304172800, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': "Hey @JeckyOH, 

Thanks for the details, I'm getting an error too and should be review and fix soon.

Regards.

______________
tested on 
* `python 2.7.13` windows 10
* `python 3.4.5` CentOS 6.5 
* `python 2.7.12` Ubuntu 16", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 24, 14, 54, 18, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
shaddygarg on (2018-03-11 16:49:40 UTC): Hey,
I will have a look into it and send a fix soon. 
Regards.

JeckyOH on (2018-03-27 22:02:00 UTC): @Ali-Razmjoo 
The reason of this issue is the ImportError of pycurl module in lib.brute.http_ntlm.py.
The error looks like this: 
`ImportError: pycurl: libcurl link-time ssl backend (openssl) is different from compile-time ssl backend (none/other)`
It is apparent that pycurl is compiled without specifying the backend as openssl.
Here is the solution: [Solution of different backend of PyCurl between link time and compile time](http://pycurl.io/docs/latest/install.html).
Just reinstall pycurl with specifying the backend as openssl:
`pip uninstall pycurl` 
`echo PYCURL_SSL_LIBRARY=openssl` 
`pip install --compile pycurl`
I have tried to use this method on Linux Ubuntu and it can solve this issue. However, in Mac OS 10.13, it failed.
Because this is the error of compiling PyCurl, which is installed through requirements.txt and I`m afraid of disrupting the structure of the project, I cannot provide a PR to solve this problem.

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2018-04-24 14:54:18 UTC): Hey @JeckyOH, 

Thanks for the details, I'm getting an error too and should be review and fix soon.

Regards.

______________
tested on 
* `python 2.7.13` windows 10
* `python 3.4.5` CentOS 6.5 
* `python 2.7.12` Ubuntu 16

title: New language library
body:
Hello,

As the framework is growing, I think the existing language library I created to keep the message is not good enough for a bigger framework, using numbers make conflicts in PRs. I think it's better to change it before framework gets bigger.

my idea is, use the same libs structure, but use messages instead of numbers.


```python
#!/usr/bin/env python
# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-


def all_messages():
    """
    keep all messages in en
    Returns:
        all messages in JSON
    """
    return \
        {
            "start_message": "Nettacker engine started ...\n\n",
            "help_options": "python nettacker.py [options]",
            "help_menu": "Show Nettacker Help Menu",
             etc...
        }

```

let me know if anyone would like to work on this. it has **priority** to fix and update documentation.

Best Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 372047577, 'issue_id': 304078856, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'I understand the point and I am willing to help with this. Do I have to create those messages myself or will you give me the details because there are 180 total messages, and what about the different languages? Do I need to do this for all the languages or just english?', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 10, 17, 32, 59, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 372049644, 'issue_id': 304078856, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hello,

thank you for your question, no English is in priority, also it just needs to change the identifier number, and find the message in the framework and replace it.
e.g.
```
message(language, "start_message")
```

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 10, 17, 54, 59, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 372063484, 'issue_id': 304078856, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'I am having a little trouble understanding the problem.

like for example, we are giving numbers (1-180) for messages in our current method for fetching data from languages, you want me to change them from 
def all_messages():
 ``   return 
        {
            "0": "Nettacker engine started ...\n\n",
            "1": "python nettacker.py [options]",
            "2": "Show Nettacker Help Menu",
            "3": "Please read license and agreements https://github.com/viraint$
            "4": "Engine",
            "5": "Engine input options",
            "6": "select a language {0}",
            "7": "scan all IPs in the range",
}``

to

``   return 
        {
            "scan_started": "Nettacker engine started ...\n\n",
            "options": "python nettacker.py [options]",
            "help_menu": "Show Nettacker Help Menu",
            "license": "Please read license and agreements https://github.com/viraint$
            "engine": "Engine",
            "input_options": "Engine input options",
            "select_lang": "select a language {0}",
            "scan_ip_ranges": "scan all IPs in the range",
}``

in all the libraries as well as in the /lib/language/messages_en.py

so can I add those names scan_started, options, help_menu, license, etc. by myself or do I need to follow any method?

Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 10, 20, 27, 36, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 372071670, 'issue_id': 304078856, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey,

if you mean choosing an id name, yes you may do it yourself, there are no any methods, just you may see what are they about and change them.

your example is also fine.

```
return { "scan_started": "Nettacker engine started ...\n\n", "options": "python nettacker.py [options]", "help_menu": "Show Nettacker Help Menu", "license": "Please read license and agreements https://github.com/viraint$ "engine": "Engine", "input_options": "Engine input options", "select_lang": "select a language {0}", "scan_ip_ranges": "scan all IPs in the range", }
```

Thanks.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 10, 22, 19, 44, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 372072172, 'issue_id': 304078856, 'author': 'pradeepjairamani', 'body': 'ok, I will solve this issue as soon as I can.

Best Regards', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 10, 22, 28, 37, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 372126770, 'issue_id': 304078856, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Thank you @pradeepjairamani. fixed.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 11, 16, 8, 39, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 383681060, 'issue_id': 304078856, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hey,

I applied changes to all languages lib using google translate API, I will open a new issue to get help from contributors to upgrade the quality of the messages

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 4, 23, 18, 45, 17, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]

in all the libraries as well as in the /lib/language/messages_en.py

title: A better ICMP library
body:
Hello,

I just notice that in #47 the `lib/icmp` and `icmp_scan` need to run as root to be working, I glad if someone can give us a better solution and contribute a new lib and replace the libraries.

let me know if anyone has any idea.

Best Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo
labels: [('enhancement', None), ('help wanted', None), ('Version 0.0.3', 'Must be done for releasing Nettacker v0.0.3')]
comments_list:
[{'comment_id': 372016973, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': "Hey @Ali-Razmjoo, 
I read about the issue of running icmp scan as root but I can't seem to find a possible solution. This is because we need to create a raw socket while sending a icmp packet and linux doesn't allow creation of raw sockets without root privileges. Alternatively we can use the ping command to run in the background using os.system('ping host'). But it won't serve the same purpose as that of a full fledged icmp library. So, I think we should implement it in the following way.
1. Check if the user logged in has root privileges
2. If it has root permissions, use the existing library to perform the task
3. Otherwise we can resort to os.system('ping host')

Regards.", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 10, 9, 37, 23, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 372053371, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'shaddygarg', 'body': 'I would like to know your views on the above implementation.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 10, 18, 34, 24, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 372134446, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'Hello,

Please let me research on this topic, I will get back to you soon, thank you for sharing your solution.

Regards.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2018, 3, 11, 17, 50, 19, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 716679652, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'pallav12', 'body': 'Hello, 
icmp_scannning is just a way to know if target is active, we can do this with simple ping like this
``
import os

hostname = "google.com" #example

response = os.system("ping -c 1 " + hostname)
if response == 0:

  print hostname, 'is up!'

else:

  print hostname, 'is down!'

``
am I missing something?', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2020, 10, 26, 16, 49, 5, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 717114805, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'it gets extra time to do that, I think we are going to focus on docker image instead to avoid such issues.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2020, 10, 27, 9, 40, 16, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 717375407, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'securestep9', 'body': '@pallav12  the whole idea of Nettacker is to be 100% in python and not dependent on other tools installed in OS like nmap/ping etc-  calling an OS command is not scaleable in terms of pythons multi-threading. Most people run nettacker in Kali Linux as root anyway and can also use it in docker as @Ali-Razmjoo has already mentioned.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2020, 10, 27, 16, 44, 59, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 717762053, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'pallav12', 'body': 'Ohh okay, makes sense', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2020, 10, 28, 7, 51, 10, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 733897616, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'abinpaul1', 'body': '[icmplib](https://github.com/ValentinBELYN/icmplib) is a new library which provides a pure Python implementation of the ICMP protocol along with the option of running as non-root.
 Would it make sense to modify the implementation to make use of icmplib', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2020, 11, 25, 19, 6, 22, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 770868495, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': '@abinpaul1 👍 

yeah we will add this as dependecy https://pypi.org/project/icmplib/', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2021, 2, 1, 13, 46, 50, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 791257919, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'abinpaul1', 'body': '@Ali-Razmjoo I would be happy to work on this. However the library is only compatible with python 3.6+. 
So I think I could go about it in two ways
- Keep the current implementation and use the new library if python version is more than 3.6
- Replace the current implmentation

I have opened a sample pull request using the second idea.  Do let me know your feedback, I could modify it as necessary.', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2021, 3, 5, 8, 36, 8, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 916430759, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'Ali-Razmjoo', 'body': 'done in #440', 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2021, 9, 9, 20, 57, 34, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}, {'comment_id': 916601493, 'issue_id': 297986005, 'author': 'abinpaul1', 'body': "Hi
I could see a lot of changes made in the PR,
However it seems the ICMP implementation still requires root to run. Was the idea to use 'icmplib' (which provides an option to run ping as non root) dropped", 'created_at': datetime.datetime(2021, 9, 10, 3, 25, 14, tzinfo=datetime.timezone.utc)}]
comment_thread:
shaddygarg on (2018-03-10 09:37:23 UTC): Hey @Ali-Razmjoo, 
I read about the issue of running icmp scan as root but I can't seem to find a possible solution. This is because we need to create a raw socket while sending a icmp packet and linux doesn't allow creation of raw sockets without root privileges. Alternatively we can use the ping command to run in the background using os.system('ping host'). But it won't serve the same purpose as that of a full fledged icmp library. So, I think we should implement it in the following way.
1. Check if the user logged in has root privileges
2. If it has root permissions, use the existing library to perform the task
3. Otherwise we can resort to os.system('ping host')

Regards.

shaddygarg on (2018-03-10 18:34:24 UTC): I would like to know your views on the above implementation.

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2018-03-11 17:50:19 UTC): Hello,

Please let me research on this topic, I will get back to you soon, thank you for sharing your solution.

Regards.

pallav12 on (2020-10-26 16:49:05 UTC): Hello, 
icmp_scannning is just a way to know if target is active, we can do this with simple ping like this
``
import os

hostname = "google.com" #example

response = os.system("ping -c 1 " + hostname)
if response == 0:

  print hostname, 'is up!'

else:

  print hostname, 'is down!'

``
am I missing something?

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2020-10-27 09:40:16 UTC): it gets extra time to do that, I think we are going to focus on docker image instead to avoid such issues.

securestep9 on (2020-10-27 16:44:59 UTC): @pallav12  the whole idea of Nettacker is to be 100% in python and not dependent on other tools installed in OS like nmap/ping etc-  calling an OS command is not scaleable in terms of pythons multi-threading. Most people run nettacker in Kali Linux as root anyway and can also use it in docker as @Ali-Razmjoo has already mentioned.

pallav12 on (2020-10-28 07:51:10 UTC): Ohh okay, makes sense

abinpaul1 on (2020-11-25 19:06:22 UTC): [icmplib](https://github.com/ValentinBELYN/icmplib) is a new library which provides a pure Python implementation of the ICMP protocol along with the option of running as non-root.
 Would it make sense to modify the implementation to make use of icmplib

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2021-02-01 13:46:50 UTC): @abinpaul1 👍 

yeah we will add this as dependecy https://pypi.org/project/icmplib/

abinpaul1 on (2021-03-05 08:36:08 UTC): @Ali-Razmjoo I would be happy to work on this. However the library is only compatible with python 3.6+. 
So I think I could go about it in two ways
- Keep the current implementation and use the new library if python version is more than 3.6
- Replace the current implmentation

I have opened a sample pull request using the second idea.  Do let me know your feedback, I could modify it as necessary.

Ali-Razmjoo (Issue Creator) on (2021-09-09 20:57:34 UTC): done in #440

abinpaul1 on (2021-09-10 03:25:14 UTC): Hi
I could see a lot of changes made in the PR,
However it seems the ICMP implementation still requires root to run. Was the idea to use 'icmplib' (which provides an option to run ping as non root) dropped

title: add retries to database queries
body:
Hello,

I am working on this error `[!] could not connect to the database!`, it happens when multi-threads want to execute a query together.

```
 python nettacker.py -i 192.168.1.1,192.168.1.124 -m port_scan -t 1000



   ______          __      _____ _____
  / __ \ \        / /\    / ____|  __ \
 | |  | \ \  /\  / /  \  | (___ | |__) |
 | |  | |\ \/  \/ / /\ \  \___ \|  ___/
 | |__| | \  /\  / ____ \ ____) | |     Version 0.0.1
  \____/   \/  \/_/    \_\_____/|_|     SAME
                          _   _      _   _             _
                         | \ | |    | | | |           | |
  github.com/viraintel   |  \| | ___| |_| |_ __ _  ___| | _____ _ __
  owasp.org              | . ` |/ _ \ __| __/ _` |/ __| |/ / _ \ '__|
  viraintel.com          | |\  |  __/ |_| || (_| | (__|   <  __/ |
                         |_| \_|\___|\__|\__\__,_|\___|_|\_\___|_|



[!] it's better to use thread number lower than 100, BTW we are continuing...
[+] Nettacker engine started ...


[!] you are not using the last version of OWASP Nettacker, please update.
[+] 13 modules loaded ...
[+] target 192.168.1.124 submitted!
[+] target 192.168.1.1 submitted!
[+] start attacking 192.168.1.124, 1 of 2
[+] start attacking 192.168.1.1, 2 of 2
[+] host: 192.168.1.124 port: 22 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] host: 192.168.1.1 port: 1 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] host: 192.168.1.1 port: 22 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] host: 192.168.1.124 port: 135 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] host: 192.168.1.124 port: 139 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] host: 192.168.1.1 port: 53 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] host: 192.168.1.1 port: 80 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] host: 192.168.1.1 port: 111 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] host: 192.168.1.124 port: 445 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[!] could not connect to the database!
[!] could not connect to the database!
[+] host: 192.168.1.124 port: 2179 (TCP_CONNECT) found!
[+] removing temp files!
[+] sorting results!
[+] building graph ...
[+] finish building graph!
[+] updating the database...
[+] inserting report to the database
[+] removing old logs from db

[+] done!
```

I going to solve this issue by adding a retries loop with `0.01` sleep time. let me know if you have a better idea.

Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

regarding code contributions,  it's best if you can develop a few basic modules ([issue 12](https://github.com/viraintel/OWASP-Nettacker/issues/12)). there are many exploits (old or new) and protcols and methods for brute, scan and information gathering. just choose something and share with me, then start developing a module (there is a few documentation on the wiki for developers).

title: add a filepath function
body:
Hello,

in the #31 PR, I've seen using `filepath = os.path.dirname(os.path.dirname(os.path.realpath(__file__)))` many times, It would be great if we add a function for it in the `core.load_modules` and every time we need the path we just call the function. Let me know if anyone would like to work on this.

Regards.
author: Ali-Razmjoo

```

title: setup.py is not working well
body:
Hello,

@ArianPH notice me that `setup.py` is not working well, It seems we have some issues on macOS and ubuntu. (Arian is working on the solution right now. if anyone has some ideas we are glad to hear them.

I tested it on windows, it's working fine....

Regards.
